trs: We're dying, the lion is killing us.' [Chief Kapyungu]

src: ii-peasi lɪ-mo \textbf{li}-\textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{satʊk}-\textbf{a} paa-si. \textbf{i}-\textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{sal}-\textbf{a} n=ʊ-kʊ-pugut-a n=ɪ-kɪ-tambala. \textbf{i}-\textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{bɪɪk}-\textbf{a} kangɪ n-kɪ-kapʊ
trs: One pear falls on the ground. He picks it up and cleans it with a cloth. He puts it back into the basket.' [Elisha Pear Story]

src: ɪ-n-gambɪlɪ si-ti-kʊ-j-a n=ɪ-n-dumbula m-mu-nda. ɪ-n-gambɪlɪ \textbf{tʊ}-\textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{si}-\textbf{lek}-\textbf{a} m-mi-piki
trs: \lq Monkeys don't have their hearts inside the body. Us monkeys, we leave them in the trees.' [Crocodile and Monkey]

src: po na lɪlɪno \textbf{li}-\textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{kol}-\textbf{a} \textbf{kʊkʊtɪ} \textbf{ii}-\textbf{sikʊ}. looli ɪ-n-gʊkʊ \textbf{kw}-\textbf{ag}-\textbf{a} \textbf{kʊkʊtɪ} \textbf{ka}-\textbf{balɪlo} si-lɪ paa-si, si-kʊ-lond-a ɪɪ-sindaano ɪ-jɪ sy-aly-asiime kʊ-ly-ebe
trs: \lq So even now it [Crow] takes them [little chicks] every day. As for the chickens, you find them all the time on the ground, searching for the needle that they had borrowed from Crow.' [Chickens and Crow]

src: ii-sikʊ lɪ-lɪ-ngɪ po a-al-iis-ile mwa=n-gambɪlɪ, a-al-iis-ile n=ɪ-ly-ojo \textup{\lq\lq}lɪlɪno \textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{m}-\textbf{b}-\textbf{a}=\textbf{ko} ɪɪ-heela j-angʊ, \textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{m}-\textbf{b}-\textbf{a}=\textbf{ko} ɪɪ-heela j-angʊ\textup{''} i-kʊ-job-a mu-n-jɪla
trs: Another day Mr. Monkey came, he came with anger. ``Today you're giving me my money, you're giving me my money'' he is saying on the way.' [Monkey and Tortoise]

src: lɪnga iis-ile ʊ-ne \textbf{n}-\textbf{gw}-\textbf{i}-\textbf{fis}-\textbf{a} \textbf{n}-\textbf{gʊ}-\textbf{j}-\textbf{a} kʊʊ-sofu, ʊ-gwe ʊ-job-ege nagwe ʊkʊtɪ a-kʊ-p-e ɪ-kɪ-kombe gʊ-n-kam-il-e. ʊ-ne \textbf{n}-\textbf{gʊ}-\textbf{n}-\textbf{kol}-\textbf{a} ʊkʊtɪ a-m-bʊʊl-e ɪ-fi i-kʊ-bomb-el-a!
trs: When she comes, I'll hide, I'll be in the bedroom, you talk with her so that she gives you the cup so that you can express milk for her. I'll catch her so that she tells me what she does with it!' [Killer woman]
Tomorrow I am heading to Tukuyu.' [overheard]
The sun rises early tomorrow morning.' [ET]
\lq We are defeating them tomorrow (sic!).' [ET]
In the evening I will be working in the field.' [ET]
\lq We will defeat them tomorrow.' [ET]
\lq Is s/he eating?' -- \lq No, s/he is not eating.' [ET]

src: ʊ-gʊʊso m-oolo. \textbf{a}-\textbf{ti}-\textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{bomb}-\textbf{a} n=ɪ-m-bombo na=jɪ-mo. i-kʊ-syʊngʊʊtɪl-a itolo
trs: Your father is lazy. He doesn't do any work. He just wanders around.' [Monkey and Tortoise]

src: n-sulumeenie fiijo paapo ʊlʊ n-iis-ile n-kʊ-kw-eg-a \textbf{ʊ}-\textbf{ti}-\textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{gomok}-\textbf{a} kangɪ
trs: \lq I'm very sad, because this time that I've come to pick you up you won't return.' [Crocodile and Monkey]
Tomorrow we do not work.' [ET]

src: mu-keet-ile leelo, mu-keet-ile leelo! n-iis-ile ne malafyale
trs: You have seen now! You have seen now! I have come as a king.' [Hare and Hippo]
(Default reading:) \lq S/he is angry.' [ET]
Yes, I really love him [spider].' [Hare and Spider]
He is sitting in a chair, reading a book.' [ET]
\lq A man with a goat passes. He holds a rope.' [Elisha Pear Story]
First he got angry, but now the anger is gone.' [ET]
(Default reading:) \lq S/he was angry.' [ET]

src: ʊ-lɪ n-sekele fiijo, kangɪ lɪnga ga-kɪnd-ile a-ma-sikʊ ma-nandɪ, ʊ-gwe \textbf{bo} \textbf{ʊ}-\textbf{fw}-\textbf{ile}
trs: ‎‎You are very tiny, also, when few days have passed, then you'll be dead.' [Mosquito and Ear]
When he arrives, the food will be cold.' [ET]
\lq The train stopped, but now it is moving again.' [ET]
He died last year.' [ET]
[Tortoise:] My child, where is my grindstone?

src: aah, mwa=n-gambɪlɪ a-a-kaleele fiijo. \textbf{eeg}-\textbf{ile} ʊ-lw-ala lʊ-la, \textbf{a}-\textbf{taag}-\textbf{ile} m-mi-syanjʊ
trs: \lq [Tortoise's child:] Aah, Mr. Monkey was very angry. He took that grindstone, he threw it into the bush.' [Monkey and Tortoise]

src: \textbf{iis}-\textbf{ile}=\textbf{po} ʊ-mu-ndʊ jʊ-mo, a-a-sʊʊm-aga a-ma-beele. leelo \textbf{n}-\textbf{um̩}-\textbf{bʊʊl}-\textbf{ile} ʊkʊtɪ iis-e na=a-ma-jolo
trs: Somebody came by, she was asking for breast milk. I told her to come back in the evening.' [Killer woman]
\lq The story is over.' [Monster with Guitar]
\lq They do not like to work with tools borrowed from neighbours' [Types of tools in the home] %inchoative

src: mma, \textbf{a}-\textbf{ka}-\textbf{job}-\textbf{a} bo ʊ-lʊ. a-t-ile \textup{\lq\lq}kalʊlʊ ʊ-jʊ n-heesya gw-ɪtʊ\textup{''}
trs: \lq No, he didn't speak like that. He said \lq\lq This hare's our guest.''' [Saliki and Hare]
\lq He has not arrived (yet), but he is arriving.' [ET]
\lq He is not angry (yet), but he is about to get angry.' [ET]
(Default reading:) \lq S/he was angry.' [ET]

src: po leelo ɪ-n-galamu j-aa-lɪ m-bine. \textbf{j}-\textbf{aa}-\textbf{lambaleele} a-ma-sikʊ ma-tatʊ n-nyumba
trs: \lq Lion was ill. He slept for three days in his house.' [Lion and Tortoise]

src: bo a-fik-ile kʊ-ka-aja \textbf{a}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{gon}-\textbf{ile}. n=ʊ-lʊ-bʊnjʊ a-lɪnkʊ-bʊʊk-a m-ma-tengele
trs: \lq When she arrived home, she slept. In the morning she went into the bush.' [Mfyage turns into a lion] %es sei denn, noch besseres bsp gehalten
He ran alone, Hare ran alone.
Mr. Tugutu did not run at all.
\lq He had gathered companions.

src: bo a-ba a-a-ba-bɪɪk-ile ʊ-kʊ-tɪ maelɪ jɪ-mo, maelɪ jɪ-mo, maelɪ jɪ-mo
trs: \lq Those are the ones he placed, like one mile, one mile, one mile.'%gutes bsp cleft
\lq So Hare ran alone.' [Hare and Tugutu]

src: a-a-li=ko kalʊlʊ n=ɪɪ-fubu. \textbf{ba}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{many}-\textbf{eene} fiijo. kangɪ b-angal-aga pamopeene ʊ-bʊ-sikʊ b-oosa
trs: \lq Once upon a time, Hare and Hippo were very much friends. And they used to be together the whole time.' [Hare and Hippo]

src: ijolo ky-a-li=ko ɪ-ky-amba. pa-mwanya pa-ky-amba pa-a-lɪ pa-tengaamu itolo. \textbf{ba}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{jeng}-\textbf{ile}=\textbf{po} a-ba-ndʊ ba-tatʊ
trs: \lq Long ago there was a mountain. On top of the mountain it was all peaceful. Three people had built there.' [Selfishness kills]

src: po mw-ene jʊ-la gw-a kajamba a-lɪnkʊ-bʊʊk-a kʊ-ka-aja n=ɪ-fi-ndʊ fi-la
trs: \lq Tortoise's child went home with that food.
\lq  He and his father ate.
\lq They were very happy for two days.

src: leelo bo gɪ-kɪnd-ile ɪ-mi-lʊngʊ mi-bɪlɪ, kajamba a-ka-a-buj-iisye. a-ka-a-bʊʊk-ile kw-a mwa=n-gambɪlɪ kʊ-kʊ-bɪɪk-a ɪɪ-heela
trs: \lq When two weeks passed, Tortoise had not paid. ‎‎He had not gone to Monkey's to hand over the money.

src: gw-a-kɪnd-ile ʊ-n̩-dʊngʊ gʊ-mo. gy-a-kɪnd-ile mi-bɪlɪ na=ka-mo n=ʊ-kʊ-bʊʊk-a kʊ-kʊ-bɪɪk-a
trs: \lq One week passed. Two weeks passed, not once going to hand it over.

src: po mwa=n-gambɪlɪ a-a-tɪ \textup{\lq\lq}hee. po m-bʊʊk-e kw-a kajamba kʊ-kʊ-mel-a ɪɪ-heela sy-angʊ\textup{''}
trs: \lq Then Monkey said \lq\lq Hee. ‎‎I shall go to Tortoise to demand my money.''{}
\lq He walked and walked and walked.' [Monkey and Tortoise]

src: kangɪ po bo gɪ-kɪnd-ile ɪ-mi-lʊngʊ mi-bɪlɪ, kangɪ \textbf{a}-\textbf{lɪnkʊ}-\textbf{buj}-\textbf{a} kw-a kajamba
trs: \lq When two weeks had passed, he returned again to Tortoise's.
\lq Another day Mr. Monkey came.
\lq He came with anger.

src: \textup{\lq\lq}lɪlɪno kʊ-m-ba=ko ɪɪ-heela j-angʊ, kʊ-m-ba=ko ɪɪ-heela j-angʊ\textup{''} i-kʊ-job-a mu-n-jɪla
trs: \lq\lq \lq Today you're giving me my money, you're giving me my money'', he is saying on his way.
\lq He arrived at Tortoise's.' [Monkey and Tortoise]

src: a-a-j-ile kʊ-buj-a. \textup{\lq\lq}Hahaha mwa=n-gambɪlɪ ʊ-li=po. gw-is-ile, pole! n-gʊ-p-a lɪlɪno ɪɪ-heela sy-ako\textup{''}
trs: \lq He [Tortoise] went and returned. \lq\lq Hahaha, Mr. Monkey, you are here! You have come, sorry! I'm giving you your money now.'
\lq They saw him [Tortoise] as he came from over there.
\lq Do you know, they had thrown him into the bush.
\lq He had (gone and) had a walk there.
\lq He had gone and returned.' [Monkey and Tortoise]
\lq One day, Hare met with Tugutu (a type of bird).

src: a-lɪnkʊ-tɪ \textup{\lq\lq}gwe, tugutu, ʊ-gwe! ʊ-ka-bagɪl-a ʊ-kʊ-n-gɪnd-a ʊ-ne ʊ-kʊ-bop-a, ʊ-ne n-gʊ-bop-a fiijo, m-bagiile ʊ-kʊ-kʊ-tol-a\textup{''}
trs: \lq He said \lq\lq You, Tugutu, you! You can't beat me in running, I run fast, I can beat you.''

src: ii-tugutu \textbf{ly}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{t}-\textbf{ile} \textup{\lq\lq}mma. ʊ-ka-bagɪl-a ʊ-kʊ-n-dol-a kalʊlʊ ʊ-kʊ-bop-a. tʊ-bagiile pamo ʊ-kʊ-tol-an-a, ʊ-kʊ-fwan-a\textup{''}
trs: \lq Tugutu said \lq\lq No. You, Hare, can't beat me in running. We can maybe have a tie.''{}' [Hare and Tugutu]
\lq He (Hare) said \lq\lq Ok then, tomorrow let's start to run.''{}
\lq Mr. Tugutu went.
\lq He gathered five companions.

src: paapo ba-al-iitɪk-eene na kalʊlʊ ʊ-kʊ-bop-a a-ma-eli ma-haano
trs: \lq Because they had agreed to run five miles.

src: bo ii-sikʊ ly-a kɪ-laabo, bo lɪ-fik-ile, mwa=n-dugutu \textbf{a}-\textbf{alɪ}-\textbf{m̩}-\textbf{bɪɪk}-\textbf{ile} mwa=n-dugutu n-nine pa-bw-andɪlo
trs: \lq When the next day arrived, Mr. Tugutu placed a fellow Mr. Tugutu at the start.

src: na kʊ-bʊ-malɪɪkɪlo, maeli ga-a bʊ-haano, mwa=n-dugutu ʊ-jʊ-ngɪ
trs: \lq At the finish line, the fifth mile, another Mr. Tugutu.' [Hare and Tugutu]%\footnotemark

src: po jɪ-lɪnkʊ-bʊʊk-a ʊ-kʊ-sook-a=po. po leelo \textbf{jɪ}-\textbf{ka}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{bʊʊk}-\textbf{ile} pa-bʊ-tali
trs: \lq It [snake] went and left. It did not go far.' [Python and woman]

src: ʊ-mw-ene kalʊlʊ \textbf{a}-\textbf{ka}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{meenye} ʊkʊtɪ ʊ-lw-ɪfi lʊ-nyeel-iile pa-n-sana paapo lw-a-lɪ lʊ-pepe
trs: \lq Hare himself did not know that Chameleon had jumped at his hip because he was light.' [Hare and Chameleon]

src: a-a-li=ko kajamba jʊ-mo. a-a-lɪ m-oolo fiijo. \textbf{a}-\textbf{ka}-\textbf{al}-\textbf{iigan}-\textbf{ile} ʊ-kʊ-bomb-a ɪ-m-bombo
trs: \lq There was a certain tortoise. It was very lazy. It did not like to work.' [Monkey and Tortoise]
\lq Here you've given me food. I was hungry [lit. hunger was biting me].' [Lake Kyungululu]
That is why you were speaking, it [the lock] truly is tough.' [Wage of the thieves]

src: n-kɪ-panga kɪ-la a-a-li=po ʊ-n-kiikʊlʊ ʊ-n-hɪɪji ʊ-jʊ \textbf{a}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{bomb}-\textbf{aga} ɪ-j-aa kw-ib-a ɪ-fi-ndʊ ɪ-fi ba-pɪɪj-ile a-ba-nine,
trs: In that village there was a thieving woman, who used to steal the food the others had cooked,'\\
\lq She used to take it out of earthen pots and cooking pots.

src: pa-la lɪnga a-bʊʊk-ile n-k-ookol-a ʊ-m-ooto kʊ-ba-nine, lɪnga ba-lɪ pa-nja, \textbf{a}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{kuputul}-\textbf{aga} ɪ-fi-ndʊ n=ʊ-kʊ-fyʊl-a=mo fi-mo, \textbf{a}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{bʊʊk}-\textbf{aga} na=fyo kʊ-my-ake
trs: \lq When she went to her neighbours to get fire, if they were outside she would uncover the food, take some out and go home with it.' [Thieving woman]

src: a-ba-nyambala \textbf{ba}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{fwal}-\textbf{aga} ɪ-n-gʊbo j-aa ng'ombe mu-no mu-n-sana
trs: \lq The men wore a skin of a cow here at the waist.' [Clothing long ago]\label{exPSTIPFVgen}

src: kɪ-laabo ɪ-kɪ-ngɪ Sokoni a-lɪnkʊ-bʊʊk-a kangɪ kʊ-kʊ-kʊng-ɪl-a ɪɪ-ng'ombe
trs: The next day, Sokoni went again to tie the cows.

src: p-oope a-alɪ-mmw-ag-ile ʊ-n-kasi gw-a Pakyɪndɪ i-kʊ-bomb-a bo sila$\sim$si-la ɪ-sy-a m-ma-jolo
trs: Again he found Pakyindi's wife doing just like the day before.
But to her husband she always said ``I am going to harvest cassava.''{}' [Sokoni and Pakyindi]
\lq A man was herding sheep.
\lq He had a dog.

src: popaa$\sim$po ʊ-mu-ndʊ jʊ-la a-lɪnkʊ-bʊʊk-a pa-kɪ-syanjʊ pa-kʊ-tʊʊsy-a
trs: \lq That man went into the thicket to rest.

src: lɪnga n-aa-lɪ ne laɪsi n-aa-ba-tʊʊl-aga a-ba-londo
trs: If I were president, I would help/be helping the poor.' [ET]

src: lɪnga n-aa-lɪ jo ʊ-ne n-aa-bʊʊk-aga kɪ-laabo
trs: \lq If it were me, I would go tomorrow.' [ET]
If we had not found the river, we would have died.' [ET]

src: ee ka-lʊmbʊ n-dɪ na=a-ka-balɪlo. ʊ-gwe \textbf{gw}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{lond}-\textbf{aga} bo ndɪɪli tw-ag-an-il-e
trs: \lq Yes little brother, I have time. Whenever you want, let's meet.' [overheard]

src: fiki gwe mw-inɪɪtʊ, gwe gw-a bʊ-tatʊ, gw-a-tʊ-bʊʊl-iile bo ʊ-seng-iigwe, \textbf{ʊ}-\textbf{ka}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{lek}-\textbf{aga} fiki tw-esa tʊ-seng-igw-e?
trs: Why, our friend, you the third one, did you tell us when you were cut, why did you not let all of us be cut?' [Wage of the thieves]
The child did not walk. For years it did not walk.' [Pregnant women]

src: \textbf{ba}-\textbf{k}-\textbf{eeg}-\textbf{an}-\textbf{aga} ʊ-bw-egi bʊ-la bw-a kʊ-piny-a pamo kw-i-kanisa. b-aa-lɪ n=ʊ-bw-egi ʊ-bw-a kyenyeeji
trs: \lq They did not have weddings of that type where they tie the bond maybe at church. They had weddings of an informal type.' [Life and marriage long ago]

src: a-ba-ndʊ bo a-bo bi-kʊ-bʊʊk-a kʊ-kw-asim-a ɪ-fi-bombelo ɪ-fy-a kʊ-bomb-el-a ɪ-m-bombo \textbf{bo} a-b-iinaabo \textbf{ba}-\textbf{lɪ} \textbf{pa}-\textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{tʊʊsy}-\textbf{a}
trs: \lq People like those go to borrow tools to do work with, when their fellows are resting.' [Types of tools in the home]

src: \textbf{lɪnga} \textbf{ba}-\textbf{lɪ} \textbf{pa}-\textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{sanuk}-\textbf{a} kʊʊ-nyuma kʊ-no k-oope ba-a-kyakyatɪl-aga fiijo bʊno$\sim$bʊ-no
trs: \lq When they were turning back there they would move quickly back and forward like this.' [Custom of dancing]
we still speak / we are still speaking
I've called you (pl.) to give you instructions before I die.' [Chief Kapyungu]

imt: skunk(1) 1-\textsc{narr}-1-tell-\textsc{fv} hare(1) 1-\textsc{narr}-say \phantom{\lq\lq}\textsc{aug}-meat(9) 9-be(come)\_burnt-\textsc{pfv} come-\textsc{ipfv} \textsc{1pl}-eat-\textsc{ipfv.subj} then hare(1) 1-\textsc{narr}-say yet 9-\textsc{pers} \textsc{aug}-15(\textsc{inf})-be(come)\_burnt-\textsc{fv}
src: nsyɪsyɪ a-lɪnkʊ-m̩-bʊʊl-a kalʊlʊ a-lɪnkʊ-tɪ \textup{\lq\lq}ɪɪ-nyama jɪ-p-iile, is-aga tʊ-ly-ege!\textup{''} po kalʊlʊ a-lɪnkʊ-tɪ \textup{\lq\lq}taasi. \textbf{jɪ}-\textbf{kaalɪ} \textbf{ʊ}-\textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{py}-\textbf{a}\textup{''}
trs: Skunk told Hare ``The meat is done, come let's eat!'' Hare said ``Later. It's not yet done.''{}' [Hare and Skunk]

src: ɪ-li-sikʊ ly-a kw-and-a a-a-bʊʊk-ile kʊ-kʊ-keet-a ɪ-fi-lombe muno fi-j-ɪɪl-iile ʊkʊtɪ kalɪ fi-bɪfiifwe pamo \textbf{fi}-\textbf{kaalɪ}
trs: On the first day he went to look at how the maize was looking to see if it had ripened yet or not.' [Thieving monkeys]
\lq Are you still studying?' -- \lq Yes, I still am.' [overheard]

src: i-kʊ-j-a pa-kʊ-kwel-a kangɪ, paapo ɪ-kɪ-kapʊ kɪ-mo \textbf{kɪ}-\textbf{kaalɪ} \textbf{pa}-\textbf{kw}-\textbf{isʊl}-\textbf{a}
trs: \lq He is about to climb up again, because one basket is still empty.' [Elisha Pear Story]
\lq They [the bananas] are still not ripe.' [overheard]

src: a-ba ba-ka-j-a ba-kɪlisiti \textbf{ba}-\textbf{kaalɪ} \textbf{b}-\textbf{ʊʊmɪɪliile} ʊ-lw-iho ʊ-lw-a kʊ-lond-a ʊ-kʊ-tiil-igw-a
trs: Those that are not Christians stick to the tradition of wanting to be feared.' [Should she save a life\ldots]
S/he still has not arrived home.' [ET]

src: taata ʊ-ne nalooli ɪ-fy-ʊma \textbf{n}-\textbf{gaalɪ} \textbf{n}-\textbf{ga}-\textbf{kab}-\textbf{a} ɪɪ-sala ɪ-jɪ
trs: Father [honorific], I still haven't obtained the brideprice.' [Man and his in-law]

src: m-ma-jolo n-aa-lambaleele bo ʊ-n-kʊlʊ gw-angʊ \textbf{a}-\textbf{kaalɪ} \textbf{a}-\textbf{ka}-\textbf{fik}-\textbf{a} pa-ka-aja
trs: Yesterday I went to bed when my elder brother still had not come home.' (implies: his late arrival is unusual) [ET]

src: m-ma-jolo n-aa-lambaleele bo ʊ-n-kʊlʊ gw-angʊ \textbf{a}-\textbf{kaalɪ} \textbf{ʊ}-\textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{fik}-\textbf{a} pa-ka-aja
trs: Yesterday I went to bed before my older brother arrived home.' [ET]
They are still famous.' [ET]
The fruits are still tasty.' [ET]

src: po bo a-kaalɪ mu-n-jɪla po kajamba a-a-t-ile
trs: As he [Mr. Monkey] was still on the way, Tortoise said:' [Monkey and Tortoise]
The woman is still at the market.' [ET]
\lq We were still eating. / We still used to eat.' [ET]
\lq We were still tired.' [ET]
\lq S/he constantly steals my maize.' [ET]

src: ʊ-saj-igw-ege n=ʊ-n-twa paapo na ʊlʊ \textbf{ʊ}-\textbf{kaalɪ} \textbf{ʊ}-\textbf{li}=\textbf{mo} \textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{bomb}-\textbf{a} ɪ-sy-a b-ooloolo. kangɪ lɪlɪno po ʊ-bomb-ile ɪ-n-gɪnd-ɪlɪsi kʊ-sy-a kw-and-a
trs: \lq Blessed be thou of the lord, my daughter: for thou hast shewed more kindness in the latter end than at the beginning [lit. \ldots because you still continuously do kind things and now you have done things much more kind than those in the beginning]' (Ruth 3:10)
\lq S/he constantly annoyed us.' [ET]
\lq I have been eating continually (for a whole hour).' [ET]
\lq The house has begun to get dirty, many people are entering.' [ET]
\lq I think he is playing (= is where they play).' [ET]

src: po kalʊlʊ a-lɪnkʊ-lembʊk-a. \textbf{i}-\textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{kuut}-\textbf{a} \textup{\lq\lq}hɪhɪɪ. ba-n-gom-ile, ba-n-gom-ile, ba-n-gom-ile.\textup{''} po nsyɪsyɪ \textup{\lq\lq}jw-ani a-kʊ-kom-ile?\textup{''}
trs: \lq Then Hare woke up. He cries \lq\lq Hihii. They've beaten me, they've beaten me, they've beaten me.'' Skunk: \lq\lq Who's beaten you?'' [Hare and Skunk]

src: po ʊ-m-fimba gw-ake gw-a n-nyambala jʊ-la, a-lɪnkw-a kʊ-syɪl-a. a-lɪnkw-a kʊ-bɪɪk-ɪl-a ii-pumba n=ʊ-kʊ-syɪl-a kʊ-la
trs: \lq The corpse of that man, he went and buried it. He went and put it in a grave and buried it there.
\lq His [killer's] wife does not know anything.' [Man and his in-law]

src: bo bi-kʊ-gomok-a mu-n-jɪla, kalʊlʊ a-lɪnkʊ-jɪ-bʊʊl-a ɪɪ-fubu a-lɪnkʊ-tɪ \textup{\lq\lq}ba-kʊ-tuufiifye fiijo ʊ-gwe ʊkʊtɪ ʊ-lɪ n-nunu, looli fi-fy-ɪma fy-ako fi-kɪnd-ɪliile ʊ-bʊ-nywamu, ba-t-ile ʊ-pungusy-e\textup{''}.
trs: \lq As they were on the road returning, Hare told Hippo, ``They've praised you a lot, that you're a good person, but your thighs are too big, they have said you should lose weight.''{}
\lq But gosh, Hare wants meat for eating.' [Hare and Hippo]

src: kalʊlʊ a-lɪnkw-angal-a pala$\sim$pa-la kɪsita kʊ-lʊ-bon-a ʊ-lʊ-bʊbi.
trs: Hare stayed right there without seeing Spider.
\lq Gosh, Spider has gone home.' [Hare and Spider]

src: a-a-kalang-ile ii-fumbɪ lɪ-la. \textbf{ngɪmba} ii-fumbɪ \textup{(}\textbf{ø}\textup{)} ly-a sota
trs: \lq She fried that egg. Gosh, that egg is Python's.' [Python and woman]
\lq When he finished his work, he left and went home.' [Hare and Hippo]

src: po \textbf{bo} ɪ-li-ndʊ lɪ-la \textbf{lɪ}-\textbf{gon}-\textbf{ile} itolo ba-aly-eg-ile a-m-ɪɪsi ga-la
trs: \lq When that monster was deeply asleep they took that water.' [Monster with guitar]
\lq As it [child] was singing, it [snake] became fat.' [Snake and children]
\lq Before she arrived there, she met a person on the way.' [Throw away the child]
\lq When we were little we went to Dar es Salaam.'  [ET]

src: po \textbf{bo} \textbf{ba}-\textbf{ti}-\textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{j}-\textbf{aag}-\textbf{a} po ɪ-ly-ebe ly-al-iis-ile ʊ-kw-and-a ʊ-kʊ-kol-a ʊ-tw-ana tw-a n-gʊkʊ
srcwordshtml: ba-ti-kʊ-j-aag-a
trs: \lq As/while they were not finding it [needle], Crow came, beginning to catch the little children of the chickens.' [Chickens and Crow]

src: \textbf{bo} \textbf{ga}-\textbf{kɪnd}-\textbf{ile} a-ma-sikʊ a-ma-longo ma-na a-ka-aja a-ka-a Ninibe ki-kʊ-pyut-igw-aga
trs: \lq Yet forty days, and Nineveh shall be overthrown.' (Jonah 3:4)

src: a-ba-ndʊ ba-la ba-lɪnkʊ-buj-a kʊ-ka-aja, \textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{no} \textbf{ba}-\textbf{kol}-\textbf{ile} a-ma-boko ga-abo m-mi-tʊ
trs: ‎‎Those people returned home with their hands on their heads.' [Thieving monkeys]

src: ba-lɪnkʊ-bʊʊk-a na=gyo kʊ-my-abo n=ʊ-lʊ-saalo ʊ-lʊ-nywamu fiijo \textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{no} \textbf{bi}-\textbf{kw}-\textbf{ɪmb}-\textbf{a} ɪɪ-nyɪmbo
trs: They went home with them [monkey's tails], very happy and singing songs.' [Thieving monkeys]

src: po \textbf{lɪnga} \textbf{ba}-\textbf{n}-\textbf{swɪl}-\textbf{ile} po ʊ-mw-ana a-a-j-aga na=a-ma-ka fiijo
trs: \lq When they had fed it, the child would become very strong.' [Clothing long ago]
\lq When you look at it [water], it is black' [Selfishness kills]
\lq ‎‎When the evening has come, then you can climb down.' [Mfyage turns into a lion]
\lq If the food was on the table [on that occasion] then they ate it.' [ET]

src: lɪlɪno \textbf{lɪnga} ʊ-jo ʊ-gwise gw-a n̩-dʊme \textbf{a}-\textbf{ka}-\textbf{alɪ}-\textbf{m̩}-\textbf{bonwile} ʊ-n-kasi gw-a mw-anaake, po i-kʊ-bomb-aga bʊle$\sim$bʊle?
trs: Nowadays, if the father of the husband has not paid the wife of his child, then what will she do?' [Should she save a life\ldots]
\lq Every time after working just a bit I find myself tired.' [ET]
\lq Every time she went down to the ground she would become a lion.' [Mfyage turns into a lion]
Sambuka became angry in her heart that she [Asia] was leaving her alone.' [Juma, Asia and Sambuka]

src: po a-lɪnkw-ag-a kajamba \textbf{i}-\textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{sook}-\textbf{a}, \textbf{a}-\textbf{fwele} ɪ-kɪ-tili, n=ii-koti ly-ake, \textbf{a}-\textbf{kol}-\textbf{ile} n=ɪ-n-gili j-aa kw-end-el-a, ɪ-kɪ-ngoti
trs: He [Monkey] found Tortoise coming out, wearing a hat and his coat, holding a stick for walking,  a walking stick.' [Monkey and Tortoise]

src: bo a-fik-ile pa-la a-lɪnkʊ-sy-ag-a ɪ-n-gambɪlɪ i-haano \textbf{si}-\textbf{fi}-\textbf{fungamiile} ɪ-fi-lombe mu-n̩-gʊnda gw-ake, \textbf{si}-\textbf{lɪ} \textbf{pa}-\textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{ly}-\textbf{a}
trs: When he arrived there, he found five monkeys had devastated the maize in his field and were eating.' [Thieving monkeys]

src: ii-sikʊ lɪ-mo kalʊlʊ bo i-kʊ-jaat-a a-lɪnkʊ-fi-bon-a ɪ-fi-lombe mu-n̩-gʊnda \textbf{fi}-\textbf{bɪfiifwe}
trs: \lq One day Hare, while he was taking a walk, saw that the maize in the field was ripe.' [Saliki and Hare]
Then he heard it as there was a sound ``Káa!'' [of a sickle swinging]' [Wage of the thieves]
\lq He told them what had happened in his house.' [Killer woman]

src: bo ba-gomwike kʊ-malafyale gw-abo, ba-alɪ-m-pangiile ɪ-sy-\textbf{a} \textbf{kʊ}-\textbf{tɪ} ʊ-n-nuguna \textbf{a}-\textbf{fug}-\textbf{ile} ɪ-n-galamu
trs: When they returned to their chief, they told him that his younger brother had tamed a lion.' [Chief Kapyungu]

src: po tw-a-many-aga ʊkʊtɪ kʊ-la ʊ-bw-ite \textbf{bʊ}-\textbf{kol}-\textbf{eene} ʊ-bw-a kʊ-mog-a
trs: \lq Then we would know that a dancing competition was being held.' [Custom of dancing]

src: ijolo n-k-iisʊ ky-a Tʊkʊjʊ, ba-a-li=ko a-ba-ndʊ \textbf{a}-\textbf{ba} \textbf{ba}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{lɪm}-\textbf{aga} ɪ-mi-gʊnda gy-abo kɪfuki na=a-ma-tengele
trs: \lq Long ago in Tukuyu there were people who were farming their fields near the forest.' [Thieving monkeys]
\lq The relatives of that child that the monster had caught listened.

src: ɪɪ-nine j-oope jɪ-lɪnkʊ-kong-a muu-nyuma pa-kɪ-syanjʊ \textbf{a}-\textbf{pa} \textbf{j}-\textbf{aa}-\textbf{syele} ɪɪ-nyama
trs: \lq The other dog followed behind to the thicket where the meat had been left.' [Dogs laughed at each other]

src: Juma a-lɪnkʊ-swig-a fiijo kʊ-ma-syʊ a-ga \textbf{a}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{job}-\textbf{aga} Sambʊka
trs: \lq Juma wondered much about the words that Sambuka had been saying.' [Juma, Asia and Sambuka]

src: bo ka-kɪnd-ile a-ka-balɪlo ka-nandɪ ʊ-n-kʊlʊmba a-lɪnkʊ-lond-a ʊ-bʊ-nyafyale bo \textbf{ʊ}-\textbf{bʊ} \textbf{a}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{lɪ} na=bo ʊ-gwise
trs: \lq After a little while the elder brother wanted a chiefdom just like the one his father had had.' [Chief Kapyungu] % cop
\lq He drove the spear downwards. He stabbed that one that was hidden below.' [Invaders]
\lq He met the dog that had eaten the meat.
\lq He [dog who has eaten the meet] asked \lq\lq My friend, where are you going?''{}
\lq The dog that had hunted said \lq\lq I am going to finish my meat.''{}

src: ɪ-m-bwa \textbf{ɪ}-\textbf{jɪ} \textbf{jɪ}-\textbf{ka}-\textbf{fwɪm}-\textbf{a}=\textbf{po} jɪ-lɪnkʊ-tɪ \textup{\lq\lq}ɪɪ-nyama ɪ-jɪ gw-a-syesye n-d-iile ʊ-ne\textup{''}
trs: \lq The dog that had not hunted said \lq\lq The meat you left over, I ate it.''{}' [Dogs laughed at each other]

src: Ngateele a-al-iinogwine fiijo kangɪ sy-alɪ-m̩-bab-ile mu-n-dumbula, paapo a-al-iib-ɪl-iigwe ɪ-fi-ndʊ \textbf{ɪ}-\textbf{fi} \textbf{a}-\textbf{ba}-\textbf{pɪɪj}-\textbf{ile} a-ba-heesya ba-ake
trs: \lq Ngateele thought much and it hurt her in her heart, because she was robbed of the food she had cooked for her guests.' [Thieving woman]
\lq Those who were near to the bush would cut it [grass] and sell it to those who wanted it.' [Nyakyusa houses of long ago]

src: n-kɪ-panga kɪ-la a-a-li=po ʊ-n-kiikʊlʊ ʊ-n-hɪɪji ʊ-jʊ a-a-bomb-aga ɪ-j-aa kw-ib-a ɪ-fi-ndʊ \textbf{ɪ}-\textbf{fi} \textbf{ba}-\textbf{pɪɪj}-\textbf{ile} a-ba-nine
trs: \lq In that village there was a thieving woman, who used to steal the food the others had cooked.' [Thieving woman] %bsp zum teil schon verwendet in pst.ipfv, aber zu gut um es rauszulassen
\lq Elephant called Lion, who is the second [in rank].' [Hare and Chameleon]
\lq Also there was bamboo from which they tap this beer they call bamboo beer.' [Nyakyusa houses of long ago]
